title: The Underground City; Or, The Black Indies; (Sometimes Called The Child of the Cavern)
author: Verne, Jules
snippet: At length thehead of the loch was reached, and the SINCLAIR stopped at Inversnaid.

title: The Underground City; Or, The Black Indies; (Sometimes Called The Child of the Cavern)
author: Verne, Jules
snippet: As the SINCLAIR advanced along the base of the mountain, the countrybecame more and more abrupt in character.

title: The Underground City; Or, The Black Indies; (Sometimes Called The Child of the Cavern)
author: Verne, Jules
snippet: Then, theSINCLAIR turning northward, the tourists gazed upon Ben Lomond, toweringnearly 3,000 feet above the level of the lake.

title: The Underground City; Or, The Black Indies; (Sometimes Called The Child of the Cavern)
author: Verne, Jules
snippet: The SINCLAIR steamed her way among them, while between them glimpsescould be had of quiet valleys, or wild rocky gorges on the mainland.

title: The Underground City; Or, The Black Indies; (Sometimes Called The Child of the Cavern)
author: Verne, Jules
snippet: A steamboat, the SINCLAIR by name, awaited tourists about to make theexcursion to the lakes.

title: Tales of a Grandfather ... [ser. 1-3.] With notes.
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: When Glengarry, one of their ablest chiefs, joined thearmy at Perth, he was anxious that the western clans should keep separate fromthose first assembled at Perth, and act in conjunction with the forces of the Earlof Huntly; and it was proposed to Sinclair to join in this sort of association, bywhich the army would in fact have been effectually separated into two parts.

title: The Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott. (Supplementary volume: containing notes, historical and illustrative, by the author, glossary, etc.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: WhenGlengarry, one oftheir ablest chiefs, joined the armyat Perth, he was anxious that the western clansshould keep separate from those first assembled atPerth, and act in conjunction with the forces of lheEarl of Hunlly; and it was proposed to Sinclair tojoin in this sort of association, by which the armywould in fact have been effectually separated intotwo parts.
